docs.lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics asked a Federal court today to overturn regulations aimed at guaranteeing food and medical attention for severely handicapped newborn babies, contending that the rules could actually cause harm to the infants. The lawsuit by the academy, which represents 24,000 pediatricians, argued that the regulations should not be permitted to take effect without more reaction from the public. The rules were published in the Federal Register March 7 and are to take effect Tuesday.

headline.main: DOCTORS ASSAIL RULES ON HANDICAPPED INFANTS

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN members of the working mothers' group of the Financial Women's Association of New York get together, they discuss not only interest rates and inflation but also pregnancy and nutrition. ''Expectant mothers are very careful to eat the right foods these days,'' said Denise McLaughlin, a member of the association board of directors. Miss McLaughlin, vice president of the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, has given up coffee and almost all wine because she is concerned about reports that caffeine and alcohol may cause birth defects. She drinks water and decaffeinated tea at work and juice and club soda at home. Whenever she and her husband, Arthur Kirsch, have dinner at a restaurant, they either do without wine or order only a half bottle.
